I. 

THE PROPOSAL 

I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed grant 

1. 
to the Kingdom of Bhutan for the Rural Renewable Energy Development Project.1 
 
2. 
The project will help Bhutan expand rural electrification to all households, and sustain its 
operations  and  energy  security  through  a  mix  of  clean  energy  sourced  from  hydropower,  solar, 
wind, and biogas.2 
 

II. 

THE PROJECT 

Rationale 

 
A. 
 
3. 
Bhutan is endowed with abundant natural and renewable energy resources. Almost 100% 
of the country's power generation (about 1,500 megawatts [MW]) is based on hydropower. Of the 
total power generated, 70% is exported to India, and power exports account for more than 40% of 
national revenue. Nevertheless, mountainous terrain and the resultant difficulties of grid extension 
have  kept  a  large  percentage  of  the  rural  population  out  of  access  to  clean  energy.  Traditional 
fuels, such as kerosene and fuelwood, cause indoor pollution and health burdens, particularly on 
women and children in rural households.  
 
4. 
For the purpose of poverty alleviation, the Government of Bhutan has established a goal of 
electrifying  all  rural  households  during  the  Tenth  Five-Year  Plan. 3  Since  1995,  the  Asian 
Development  Bank  (ADB)  has  supported  Bhutan  in  expanding  rural  electrification  through  four 
consecutive  loan  and  grant  projects,  covering  30,000  households,  or  35%  of  the  total  rural 
population in Bhutan.4 As of December 2009, Bhutan had achieved rural electrification of 60% of 
all  households,  and  this  figure  is  expected  to  reach  84%  by  2012  on  the  completion  of  two 
ongoing  projects  supported  by  ADB  and  the  Japan  International  Cooperation  Agency  (JICA).5 
After  the  completion  of  the  government’s  own  rural  electrification  program,  which  is  running  in 
parallel  with  those  projects,  around  8,500  households  will  still  be  left  for  further  electrification 
through grid extension. Those households are scattered in remote areas throughout the country 
and  most  of  them  are  in  the  central  and  eastern  regions  of  Bhutan,  which  are  far  from  the 
commercial  and  industrial  centers  in  the  western  region.  As  a  state-owned  transmission  and 
distribution  utility,  the  Bhutan  Power  Corporation  (BPC)  is  responsible  for  implementing  on-grid 
rural electrification, while the Department of Energy (DOE) under the Ministry of Economic Affairs 
looks after implementing off-grid rural electrification.  
 
5. 
To achieve the overarching goal of electricity for all, 1,896 additional households will need 
to be electrified on an off-grid basis. Due to the wide spread and low density of rural communities 
and  the  mountainous  terrain,  it  is  costly  and  difficult  to  extend  distribution  lines  to  provide 
electricity  to  remote  and  isolated  villages.  Where  the  grid  extension  is  assessed  economically

systems.  Most  of  them  have  been  installed  in  rural  households  under  donor-assisted  grant

the National Solar Electrification Program. However, there were few tracking systems to identify 
the exact location and working condition of solar home systems installed prior to 2006. This made 
it  difficult  to  conduct  regular  operations  and  maintenance  activities  or  replace  batteries  on  solar 
home systems. To tackle these operational issues, the DOE has established (i) a comprehensive 
database  system  that  records  information  about  the  solar  home  systems  installed,  and  (ii)  an 
outsourcing  operation  and  maintenance  program  through  community-based  village  technicians 
contracted  with  the  BPC. 7  To  ensure  operational  sustainability,  these  technicians  will  have 
technical  backup  support,  regular  training,  and  supervision  from  BPC  customer  service  centers. 
Their  services  will  cover  both  off-grid  and  remote  on-grid  areas  where  minor  repairs  and 
maintenance, customer care, billing, and collection work are included.   
 
6. 
In Bhutan, domestic demand for electricity has been growing by 17% per year on average 
over  these  5  years.  This  demand  growth  is  expected  to  escalate  in  the  long  run  due  to  the 
increase  in  the  number  of  new  customers  connecting  as  ongoing  rural  electrification  is 
completed.8 Experiences  with  rural  electrification  indicate  that  overall  electricity  consumption  will 
increase as rural economies develop and households increasingly rely on electricity and acquire 
new appliances. Bhutan has already experienced power shortages, particularly in the dry winter 
periods  when  hydropower  generation  is  reduced  due  to  low  river  flows.  Despite  the  nation's 
annual net power surplus, Bhutan’s power generation from run-of-the-river hydropower plants is 
very  seasonal,  as  the  water  flows  and  levels  are  difficult  to  control  in  the  dry  season. 
Consequently, the existing generation systems have been unable to meet the recent fast-growing 
demand during the dry winter peak periods. In the last two winters, the BPC has been forced to 
limit power supply to industry, resulting in economic and revenue losses. In the 2010 winter, it is 
estimated that the power generation shortfall against the growing demand will be around 25 MW, 
which will have significant impacts on industry’s production.9 The Druk Green Power Corporation 
(a  state-owned  generation  company)  also  reported  that  levels  of  water  flow  in  rivers  had  been 
declining  in  the  past  2  years  due  to  changes  of  monsoon  patterns,  leading  to  less  hydropower 
production. Increased power imports from India would not be feasible due to more severe power 
deficits on the Indian side.  
 
7. 
To  improve  national  energy  security,  the  DOE  intends  to  issue  the  Renewable  Energy 
Policy  that  aims  to  promote  alternative  renewable  energy  sources  other  than  large  hydropower, 
and  diversify  the  energy  supply  base  through  wind,  solar,  biomass,  and  small  and  micro 
hydropower.10 Based on wind mapping data and subsequent surveys,11 the pilot wind power mills

will  need  to  be  developed  to  meet  the  country’s  demand  without  reducing  exports  of  surplus

8. 
While electricity is useful for lighting, fuelwood is still the main source of primary energy for 
cooking  and  heating  in  rural  areas,  where  about  70%  of  the  country's  population  lives.  While 
urban households mostly use modern cleaner energy (e.g., electricity and/or liquefied petroleum 
gas) for cooking, rural households depend heavily on fuelwood,13 which emits indoor air pollutants 
and poses a health hazard.14 Consumption of fuelwood in Bhutan is about 1.2 tons per capita per 
year,  which  is  the  highest  consumption  in  the  world  (and  twice  as  high  as  Nepal).  The  survey 
conducted under the ADB project preparatory technical assistance (TA) indicated that most rural 
people often cut down trees in  exchange  with payments  of fuelwood  royalty to the government. 
This is partly because the fuelwood royalty is cheaper than alternatives, and it is getting difficult to 
collect adequate fuelwood in nearby forests. This suggests that there is a need to provide access 
to  reliable  and  clean  cooking  fuels  and  technology  so  as  to  improve  inefficient  energy 
consumption,  avoid  deforestation,  and  meet  the  energy  demand  for  the  rural  population  in  an 
affordable manner. Biogas technology simply converts cattle dung to clean and renewable biogas, 
and  this  can  replace  polluting  fuelwood  and  more  expensive  kerosene  and  liquefied  petroleum 
gas. It is becoming popular in some developing countries (e.g., Bangladesh, Nepal, and Viet Nam) 
on a commercial basis through private service providers. The market assessment indicates that 
there are potentially 16,000 households that could become biogas users in Bhutan.15 
 
Rural  electrification  as  well  as  alternative  renewable  energy  development  will  not  only 
9. 
address local energy demand and national energy security but will also act as social interventions 
for  the  poor,  as  they  help  diversify  income-earning  activities  in  rural  areas.  Small  business 
establishments sprout where electricity is available. Electric rice mills and flour mills will increase 
supplementary  income,  and  the  by-product  of  the  biogas  plants  (odorless  bio-slurry)  is  an 
excellent  organic  fertilizer  that  will  increase  productivity  for  rural  farmers.  It  is  evident  that 
electrification  will  also  increase  socioeconomic  benefits  in  the  areas  of  education  and  health. 
Comprehensive activities under the project are thus expected to improve the quality of life and the 
standard of living in rural areas, where more than 90% of poor people live. The project will also 
contribute  to  environmental  sustainability  by  reducing  deforestation  and  greenhouse  gas 
emissions.

B. 

Impact and Outcome 
 
11.  
The impact of the project will be to sustain inclusive economic growth through widening 
the access to reliable and affordable clean energy services. As an outcome, the coverage and 
mix of clean energy supply will be expanded throughout the country in a sustainable manner. In 
particular,  the  project  will  contribute  to  achieving  100%  rural  electrification  of  all  households 
identified in the Rural Electrification Master Plan 2005, and diversifying energy supply sources 
to meet a growing demand, particularly in the winter dry seasons.  
 
C. 

12.

To  achieve  electricity  for  all  as  defined  under  the  Rural  Electrification  Master  Plan, 
13. 
around  8,500  households  are  expected  to  be  electrified  by  extension  of  distribution  lines  and 
financed  by  ADB  in  parallel  with  the  Austrian  Development  Agency  (ADA)  and  JICA. 18 
Households  in  isolated  remote  areas  will  also  have  access  to  electricity  through  solar  home 
systems on  an off-grid basis. The project will also support rehabilitation of existing solar home 
systems, particularly through battery replacement.19   
 
14.  
To  deal  with  growing  demand  for  energy  along  with  expanding  rural  electrification, 
additional  alternative  energy  sources  will  need  to  be  developed.  The  pilot  wind  power  and 
biogas development is expected to help improve national energy security by diversifying energy 
resources  in  the  long  run. 20  The  pilot  wind  power  mills  will  demonstrate  the  feasibility  of 
generating  wind  power  that  will  help  alleviate  the  power  shortage  problems  in  dry  winter 
seasons,  and  enable  Bhutan  to  gain  practical  experience  in  planning,  constructing,  and 
operating wind farms before implementing them on a larger scale. The biogas development is 
expected to replace fuelwood for cooking (as electricity replaces kerosene for lighting). Biogas 
and  electricity  can  thus  complement  each  other  in  rural  households  to  reduce  indoor  pollution 
originating mainly from kerosene and fuelwood.

ADB  will  coordinate  implementation  with  ADA  and  JICA  to  support  the  on-grid  rural 
electrification  component.  To  implement  the  biogas  component,  ADB  will  also  coordinate  with 
SNV and the United Nations Development Programme (UNDP), which plans to provide a small 
number of biogas plants and related livelihood programs.29  
 
The  government  and  the  executing  agency  requested  ADB  for  advance  contracting  and 
21.  
retroactive  financing  for  procurement  of  works,  goods,  and  services.  To  ensure  sustainability  of 
off-grid rural electrification, the DOE will establish a bulk procurement and inventory management 
system for spare parts, and support village technicians for operation and maintenance of off-grid 
solar  home  systems  through  the  BPC.  The  wind  power  and  biogas  components  will  be 
implemented on a pilot basis where they are intended to establish the capacity to enable Bhutan 
to  run  a  large-scale  program  in  the  subsequent  phase.  To  ensure  implementation  of  those 
activities, each of the off-grid solar and wind power components will include individual consultants 
on a small scale, and SNV will be engaged in capacity building support for the biogas component. 
 

III. 

DUE DILIGENCE 

Technical 

 
A. 
 
22. 
The mountainous terrain, lack of road access, and low population density results in high 
capital  costs  and  slow  network  expansion  of  rural  electrification  due  to  logistical  problems. 
Therefore,  the  cost  and  time-saving  design  will  be  crucial  for  the  “last  mile”  of  on-grid  rural 
electrification.  Telescopic  poles  and  single-phase  transformers  will  be  applied  for  cost-effective 
and  easy  transport  in  remote  mountainous  areas. 30  Where  on-grid  rural  electrification  is  not 
economically  feasible,  off-grid  solar  home  systems  will  be  installed  with  maintenance-free 
batteries. Recent energy-efficient technology—such as ultra-low-power, white light-emitting-diode 
lamps—has  reduced  the  required  solar  home  system  capacity  and  capital  cost  while  increasing 
the room for electricity consumption for lighting and other small electric appliances (e.g., a radio 
and  a  cell  phone  charger).  The  biogas  plants  are  technically  simple,  and  the  plant  model  used 
widely in Nepal has been adopted based on the technical feasibility assessment done by SNV.31 It 
will be deliberate to pilot-test new energy potential of wind power technology to learn wind firm's 
construction and operations before its scaling up.  
 
B. 
 
23. 
The overall project is economically viable based on an aggregate economic internal rate of 
return of 13.9%.32 The institutional financial positions of the BPC and BDFC are also viable.33 The 
government  ensures  the  BPC’s  financial  sustainability,  which  can  be  affected  by  rural

started  a  decentralized  operation  system  and  outsourcing  arrangement  to  reduce  the  financial 
burdens  of  operation  and  maintenance  costs  in  remote  rural  areas.  To  ensure  operational 
sustainability of off-grid systems, the DOE has agreed with the BPC to outsource operation and 
maintenance  for  solar  home  systems  to  village  technicians  contracted  by  the  BPC,  and  the 
government  will  meet  the  BPC’s  costs  of  providing  these  outsourcing  services.  The  pilot  wind 
mills connected to grid systems are assessed financially feasible through free capital provision to 
the BPC, where the revenue will fully meet the operation and maintenance costs in cash terms. 
The  pilot  biogas  component  is  financially  and  economically  viable,  assuming  a  certain  level  of 
subsidy support  during the initial stage of development.  While the subsidy is required to reduce 
the  entry  barriers  to  the  biogas  market  for  rural  farmers,  the  plant  cost  will  be  contributed  to  by 
upfront equity from biogas users, and the balance will be credited through the BDFC to enhance 
market-driven  development.  The  subsidy  and  credit  are  from  the  Biogas  Fund,  which  will  be 
established  from  the  ADF  grant  and  administered  by  the  BDFC. 35 To  ensure  its  operational 
feasibility,  part  of  the  financing  will  be  used  to  create  a  capacity  and  commercial  environment 
where (i) farmers will be better educated and more aware of biogas plants, (ii) farmers will have 
access to credit that underpins any successful introduction of certified technologies, and (iii) the 
DOL,  DOE,  and  private  masons  for  the  plant  construction  will  be  fully  enabled  for  operations 
through  intensive  and  long-term  training  and  capacity  building  with  support  from  SNV. 36 The 
biogas program has initiated an application process for the clean development mechanism.  
 
C. 
 
24. 
In August 2010, the government approved a new regulatory framework on tariff pricing 
that  clarifies  segregation  between  the  regulator’s  assessment  on  cost-based  tariffs  and  the 
government’s decision on tariff subsidies sourced from the royalty energy supply. This enables 
consumers  to  know  the  cost-based  tariffs  and  subsidy  requirements;  it  will  make  the  cost 
recovery  accountable  and  the  tariff  pricing  and  subsidy  systems  transparent. 37  The  royalty 
energy will be sold at a discounted price to the BPC from the government and its revenue will be 
allocated  to  the  government’s  resources  to  sustain  operation  and  maintenance  of  overall  rural 
electrification  and  pilot  renewable  energy  subprojects  as  stipulated  in  the  provision  of  the 
Economic  Development  Policy  2010. 38  The  policy  also  defines  holistic  adaptation  of  the 
Renewable Energy Policy, which is in the process of being approved by the government.39 
 

Governance

ADB’s Anticorruption Policy (1998, as amended to date) was explained to and discussed 
25. 
with the government, DOE, and the implementing agencies. 40 The specific policy requirements 
and supplementary measures are described in the project administration manual.  
 
D. 
 
26. 
The  project  is  expected  to  promote  equitable  rural  development  and  improve  rural 
connectivity.  Access  to  electricity  will  provide  the  poor  with  equal  opportunity  to  enjoy  an 
improved  quality  of  life,  facilitating  their  participation  in  social  and  economic  activities  that  can 
contribute  to  poverty  alleviation.41 Modern  clean  energy  will  enable  women  to  equally  benefit 
through reduced time spent collecting fuelwood, pollution-free lighting and fuel, and use of rice 
cookers  and  other  electrical  appliances  that  will  reduce  indoor  smoke.  The  provision  of  clean 
energy will not only make their chores easier but will also improve their health. Respiratory and 
eye ailments are more common in women, children, and the elderly since these groups remain 
indoors  more  than  men.  The  project  will  be  implemented  in  close  coordination  with  ADB’s 
gender mainstreaming initiative.42 The initiative is expected to support training programs for the 
village  technicians  involved  in  the  operation  and  maintenance  of  rural  electrification  so  as  to 
expand female employment opportunities in rural areas. It will also provide livelihood programs 
and  training  opportunities  for  revenue-earning  activities  in  partnership  with  nongovernment 
organizations.43 The  biogas  market  is  expected  to  create  new  private  sector  opportunities  in 
rural communities for masons and service providers. 
 
E. 
 
The  project  is  classified  under  safeguard  category  B  for  environment  and  involuntary

resettlement  plan  were  prepared  following  ADB's  Safeguard  Policy  Statement  (2009)  and  the 
government's related guidelines, policies, and legislation.44 The environmental clearances were 
granted by the National Environment Commission for each of the four project components. The 
environment  management  plans  mainly  include  (i)  a  collection  system  for  used  lead-acid 
batteries  of  solar  home  systems,  and  (ii)  barriers  against  potential  wind  turbine  noise.45 While 
the project does not involve physical displacement, five households will be affected by the loss 
of  a  portion  of  their  land  (equivalent  to  less  than  10%  of  their  total  landholding)  due  to  the 
expansion of an access road to the wind power site. The government will provide the affected 
households  with  substitute  land  in  accordance  with  the  Safeguard  Policy  Statement.  The 
resettlement plan includes an entitlement matrix that ensures appropriate and fair compensation 
for  the  loss  of  private  land  and  crops.  Project  stakeholders  and  affected  people  have  been 
consulted  throughout  the  project  design  and  planning  phases. 46 A  grievance  mechanism  to 
address  stakeholder  concerns  is  included  in  the  resettlement  plan.  Project  implementation  is

F. 
 
28. 
Potential  risks  include  (i)  an  increase  in  the  cost  of  construction  materials  and 
transportation due to higher fuel prices, (ii) delays in construction due to procurement and contract 
awards, and (iii) lack of technical and operational management for alternative renewable energy 
deployment.  The  cost  and  time  overrun  risks  are  to  be  mitigated  by  (i)  adequate  physical  and 
price  contingencies,  and  cost  estimates  on  recent  actual  bid  prices  for  rural  electrification 
components;  and  (ii) advance  contracting  and  retroactive  financing.  To  mitigate  risks  related  to 
technical and operational feasibility, proven energy and labor-efficient technology will be adapted 
and capacity building and implementation support will be built into the development of alternative 
renewable  energy  components  through  consultancy  services  and  aid  coordination.  To  ensure 
operational and financial sustainability, (i) memoranda of understanding were agreed between the 
DOE  and  each  of  the  implementing  agencies,  and  (ii)  the  government  assured  any  additional 
resources through its budgetary allocation based on adequate energy royalty provision. Based on 
these mitigation measures, the overall project risks are considered low.47
